marketNews.title: US Strikes Iran, Hormuz Strait Potentially Closed
marketNews.content: US President Donald Trump announced on Sunday (22/6) that the US military has attacked three Iranian nuclear facilities, marking direct US involvement in the Israel-Iran conflict. The attack came only three days after the White House spokesperson said that the US decision to strike Iran would be determined within the next two weeks. In response, the Iranian parliament reportedly supports a plan to close the Strait of Hormuz, a shipping lane that carries about 20% of global oil supplies each day. However, the final decision to close the strait lies with Iran's National Security Council. US Secretary of State Marco Rubio said on Sunday (22/6) that he has contacted the Chinese government to prevent Iran from closing the strait. China is currently the largest importer of Iranian oil, with imports exceeding 1.8 million barrels per day in May 2025, according to vessel-tracking firm Vortexa. To date, Iran has not launched a retaliatory strike against the US. Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi said the country is considering all options to respond to the attack. Trump warned that if Iran retaliates against US assets, the United States will respond with greater force than the initial strike. Bloomberg reports that Iran currently lacks any alliance to confront the US, although China and Russia have condemned the US attack. Abbas said he will meet Russian President Vladimir Putin on Monday (23/6), but Bloomberg noted that military assistance from China and Russia will be difficult because there is no formal military relationship with Iran. The only proxy militant group that has shown support for Iran is the Houthi movement, which has announced threats targeting commercial ships and US naval vessels. Key Takeaway: In response to these developments, September 2025 Brent futures briefly jumped +5.2% to $79.4 per barrel on Monday (23/6) before falling to $76.1 intraday (+0.8%) as there was no immediate concrete response from Iran, indicating that Middle East oil supplies remain largely uninterrupted despite the escalating conflict. Stock markets reacted muted in the afternoon, with the Nikkei down -0.13%, EURO STOXX 50 down -0.44%, and S&P Futures down -0.05%. The Indonesian IDX composite (IHSG) fell -1.74%, driven mainly by large-cap stocks such as $DSSA (-5.91%), $BREN (-4.13%) and $BBRI (-1.85%). We assess that the market is still waiting to see how far Iran will respond to the US strike before prices react further, and this situation should be closely monitored by investors.

marketNews.title: Other Hot Topics to Know
marketNews.content:
1. Bank Indonesia reported that broad money (M2) grew 4.9% year-on-year in May 2025 to 9,406.6 trillion rupiah (April 2025: +5.2% YoY).
2. Medikaloka Hermina ($HEAL) director Hasmoro bought 724,600 HEAL shares at 1,380 rupiah each on 13 June 2025, total transaction value about 1 billion rupiah. After the transaction his direct ownership rose from 4.7996% to 4.8044%.
3. Deputy Minister of Energy and Mineral Resources, Yuliot Tanjung, said on Friday (20/6) that the government is considering allowing industries to import gas independently if domestic supply cannot meet demand.
4. Head of the Public Communication and Information Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation, Ernita Titis Dewi, said on Sunday (22/6) that the government's plan to implement zero-ODOL is being drafted with cross-ministerial involvement. The target is zero-ODOL vehicles by 2026, with warning phase starting July 2025 and enforcement from August 2025.
5. Head of BMKG, Dwikorita Karnawati, said on Saturday (21/6) that most of Indonesia will experience a shorter dry season than previously forecast, driven by higher rainfall, which is expected to boost rice yields. Previously BMKG had projected a normal dry season starting April 2025, peaking June-August 2025.
6. Bank DKI announced a rebranding to Bank Jakarta and a new logo on Sunday (22/6). Governor of DKI Jakarta, Pramono Anung Wibowo, tasked the new Bank Jakarta management with an IPO in 2026.

tickerNews.title: BUMI targets Wolfram mine operation in 2026
tickerNews.content: $BUMI reported that Vice President Investor Relations & Chief Economist Achmad Reza Widjaja said the Wolfram Limited mine is expected to be operational in 2026, without further detail. He also mentioned that the company aims for non-coal revenue to contribute 50% of total revenue by 2030. Previously, BUMI disclosed that the acquisition of Wolfram Limited, a copper and gold mining company, is awaiting approval from the Australian Foreign Investment Review Board.

tickerNews.title: Barito Renewables Energy secures $121.1 million credit facility
tickerNews.content: $BREN signed a credit facility of US$121.1 million with DBS Bank Ltd. and SMBC, maturing on 18 June 2030. The facility will finance a 47 MW capacity expansion through the retrofit of PLTP Darajat unit 3 and the construction of PLTP Salak unit 7.

tickerNews.title: London Sumatra Indonesia announces 2024 dividend
tickerNews.content: $LSIP will distribute a 2024 dividend of approximately 443 billion rupiah or 65 rupiah per share, representing a 30% dividend payout ratio (2023: 35%) and indicating a dividend yield of about 5.4% as of Monday (23/6). The cum-date is 30 June 2025 on the regular market, with payment on 18 July 2025.
